body:
I think so. Remember we were the ones who brought death upon the world. And animals were only allowed to be killed and eaten after the flood, when plants would no longer suffice.

The issue is never actually mentioned. Some writers seem to assume they will and others that they won't, but the latter view would be very much expected in ancient culture which viewed only humans, and sometimes only adult male humans, as having souls, so the fact that some of them disagreed at all is telling.

post.body: Will you see Fluffy again in the KoH?
post.body_html: Will you see Fluffy again in the KoH?
post.title: Are there animals in the Kingdom of Heaven?

body:
You mean the animal you cut the genitals off of, then made them your house eunuch?

God made humans as masters over all of God's creation on Earth, including the animals. This is why farm and house animals are treated like property in the Bible. And it's why, as Christians, we don't care if you castrate your house animals, even though we would certainly care if you castrated your children.

Your pets are blessings from God. You treat them as such. But don't fool yourself into thinking that your pet chose to live with you. Virtually all best case scenarios is that you saved the pet from a life as a beaten and lonely eunuch and instead made them a comfortable eunuch.

If God gives you Fluffy in heaven, it's because he loves you, not because he loves the animal. If you owned a slave, would you hope that God gives you your slave in heaven? If God loved your pet, he would reunite them with their family, not with your family.

We're pretty fucked up people. It's why we need God.

body:
Everyone but the elites is also treated like property throughout the bible, especially in the old testament. That's just how it was in ancient times, and arguably still today even though it's covered up more. And yes, there are plenty of passages supporting it, because scribes put them there hoping to control people with doctrines similar to the divine right of kings.

And in ancient times people were also regularly castrated. Scribes in the torah changed it to say it's an abomination but God calls it a blessing several times.

body:
God does not bring you to heaven as a slave, nor as an amputee.

If God brings your pet to heaven, it will not be as a slave or an amputee unless God wants YOU to be happier. But if you are in heaven you won't need anything else but God. You will thank God for the great times he gave you with your pets, and you will be happy to never be lonely or sad again.

post.title: Are there animals in the Kingdom of Heaven?

body:
I don't think an answer has been conclusively established

since God's all powerful, it seems He could maintain pets again in the afterlife as they bring us great joy

on the other hand, it's not thought that animals have immortal rational souls and hence it has been thought they were merely mortals who would not exist in the afterlife

If you doubt Jesus's statement, I should let you know that he said it in a culture which interpreted Genesis in the same way you do, and they indeed said everyone who didn't marry and pop out as many kids as possible as soon as possible is a sinner. And they could point to that quote in Genesis and indeed it would look like they were justified. Yet Jesus says *this* in the midst of all that.

> I know there is a passage where Jesus talks about this, but just in a sense, that some people are destined to stay alone and never have sex.

It's still a blessing when it's done by others or you're born that way. And staying alone is also not a "destiny", that's just another excuse to force sex and marriage on people, "that's extremely rare, it's not for you, we need to get you married and having kids". They *choose* that life "for the sake of the kingdom".

body: The idea that humans have an "immortal soul" is rooted in Greek thought. All that's mentioned in the old testament is the breath of life, and it describes all living beings, and even God. In the new testament soul is always used metaphorically, in the same sense. (This is not to say that it can't be immortal, but it isn't specified, and certainly not specifically to humans). And a "rational soul" comes from the tree of knowledge, the very thing that first killed, so there's no way that's a requirement for eternal life.

And a "rational soul" comes from the tree of knowledge, the very thing that first killed, so there's no way that's a requirement for eternal life.

body:
Choosing sexless life for the sake of kingdom, when you were not meant to, has bad consequences, and one of the reasons why are there so many pedo scandals in the church. When you were not meant to live that life, sooner or later, you'll fall, no matter how hard you try. And some people fall spectacularly hard. 

Many places in Bible talk about children as a blessing, Meanwhile I'm not aware about any parts praising sexless life as a blessing. When God told Adam and Eve to fill the Earth, I believe, this is a mission for all humanity. Do you think it was meant just for them and for no one else? Only two humans could never manage to fill the Earth, that's something possible to reach only across multiple generations. This is nothing about forcing sex to anyone since that is a natural thing for us.

I think some of the components of the idea of rationality is the ability to use logic to think things through, to have memory, and to be able to choose good and evil

parent.body:
> Choosing sexless life for the sake of kingdom, when you were not meant to, has bad consequences, and one of the reasons why are there so many pedo scandals in the church. When you were not meant to live that life, sooner or later, you'll fall, no matter how hard you try. And some people fall spectacularly hard.

No, that happens when the church *forces* people to live a sexless life. Or they're just simply corrupt religious leaders, which is why it happens just as often with married fundie pastors.

> Many places in Bible talk about children as a blessing, Meanwhile I'm not aware about any parts praising sexless life as a blessing.

Jesus called it a blessing. The man most "Christians" love 10x more than Jesus, Paul, viewed marriage as nothing more beneficial than a means to avoid shacking up. The prophets held it in high esteem, including those who were born that way. Unfortunately human nature prevails in this world and the authors of the torah harassed even those who *couldn't* have sex, along with a crap ton of other crazy laws.

> When God told Adam and Eve to fill the Earth, I believe, this is a mission for all humanity. Do you think it was meant just for them and for no one else? Only two humans could never manage to fill the Earth, that's something possible to reach only across multiple generations.

The fact that Cain was worried about other people killing him far away implies that Adam and Eve had a *lot* of kids. That's plenty to keep more generations coming. 

> This is nothing about forcing sex to anyone since that is a natural thing for us.

When you tell people who don't immediately plan on marrying and having 2.5 kids they are sinning and pressure them to do so as much as most churches do, that's almost forcing it.

body:
> You still didn't mention where did Jesus say that life without sex is blessing.

Matthew 19:10-12. And even one of the late pseudographical authors in Isaiah 56:3-5 praises it.

> I honestly never heard anyone saying that not having children is a sin.

A lot of people think it's a sin to not have a stereotypical marriage with 2.5 kids and a two-story home in an American suburb. And will shame those who don't.

> But it is weird to not have them.

You find it weird, because that is your flesh's main goal. And in fact, if you're a male, it's your flesh's *only* mission. This is why people distinguish between blood-related and adopted/married family, or even friends, because there is a deep primal desire to pass on your genes and continue your bloodline. It explains the natural preference for your own race as well. But it is unwise to serve the flesh over the spirit. Nevertheless, I suppose there is a reason Jesus said most people can't accept this, and I should not be so surprised at the amount of rejection it gets.

> Now the typical person that advocates for childless life is some progressive dumbass, that is screaming we have to save our planet and how we all have to get sterilised.

Anyone who says to their brother "you idiot!" will be in danger of death. Now I am not worthy to judge this, as I indeed don't have exactly the cleanest record myself. But it doesn't make your argument sound in good faith to me.

> And honestly, when progressives start pushing something, one can be quite sure the opposite is the right direction.

That's exactly what the devil wants you to think: "These people do some bad things, so as long as I do the opposite I'm good". I want you to understand that he controls all the institutions of this world, all the governments, all the churches, all the political parties, all the media. And when we idolize the things of this world, and follow men and institutions, we really are allowing him to lead us. Certainly I am not saying to rebel against what God has allowed to be in place. But we should not follow them, nor obey them when they tell us to do wrong. And that your leaders, or your friends, say something is okay, does not make it good. Is good defined by you? Is it up to social approval? And that your enemy does not do something, does that make it good? Is evil defined by your enemy? I tell you, no! But right and wrong are defined by two commandments: You shall love YHWH your god with all your heart, and with all your life, and with all your ability, and, you shall love your neighbor the same as yourself. If any progressive, or person of any other political movement or follower of anything else is reading this, the same goes for you.

> And even more for Christians I see no reason to turn to this. Kids are a blessing. I just don't understand why this is unfortunate for you. It is one of the best things that can happen in life, and it gives you purpose to life for (of course, except our goal to not loose our faith and reach heaven)

I, *personally*, don't like sex because sex and fallen biology are the root of so much anguish in this life. Immediately, sex reduces a person to how they look, how they act, their status. It makes you put on a fake show to try and "win" someone like an object. It causes people to fight to the death. It destroys every other gift you have, and any other capability you might have, is sacrificed by your body to optimize your success at sex. The hormones and biological instincts make you act completely irrationally and even evil, and certainly don't help your personal development either. They make you selfish on impulse to protect your genes. They force you to think a certain way and block everything else. Even my own body values sex over me, someone who has no desire to have intercourse with someone, and it gets much in the way of every other goal I have, because that's what it is wired to do. Even my brain has been completely rewired to become best at getting sex, meaning I lost every other cognitive ability I had. I'm a shell of my former self. I'm not saying sex in and of itself is a bad thing at all. But as for me, I don't want a part of it. It's not for me.

I also have no problems with children. And adoption is not out of the question for me, though it isn't on my radar right now. I just don't care for getting laid.

body:
It didn't choose to leave its parents, did it? It didn't choose to get its genitals removed.

If it chooses to spend time with you, it's because it was ripped from its birth family and doesn't know better.

When God put Adam and Eve in the Garden of Eden, he gave them the option to leave. God treats us as masters of our domain because he loves us. He does not treat us like pets. He tells us that we should accept him like children, but he does not take our genitals to force us to be perpetual children.

When I say I love God it's because has raised me like a human child of his. He let me disobey him, he saved me in the depths of my disobedience, and yet he welcomes me home with all of my scars.

I don't know if it's possible to love your pet like God loves us. Your pet had no understanding that you kept them from being an adult. Their mother and father gave birth to litters they never had the opportunity to raise. There was no choice with pets. Therefore, it's hard to say that there is real love.

body:
I can tell this is new to you, but God doesn't seem to love animals like he loves us.

He seems to be willing to give up all animals for us, since he doesn't seem to care if you abuse your own animals.

Therefore, I don't think you will see your pet in heaven. You will see God, and that is more than enough. Certainly more than we deserve. I hope that someday you realize the glory in God alone. But also realize that we treat pets much worse than God treats us. And if we treated humans like we treat pets, nobody would consider us Christian, likely not even God.

body:
Well obviously you don't use your pets as fuck toys. Eunuchs are asexual. Besides, the commandments against fucking animals comes from the concern for the humans.

Leviticus attempts to heal and prevent disease for humans, but it straight up dismisses animals, categorically in some cases, as irredeemable.

I get why this is hard for you, but we gotta be honest with each other. If you live in the US, you generally maim your pets because you don't want to have to love them as they are. You want to love them for how you want them to be.

I feel like it is shameful to maim God's creation unnecessarily, but God told Adam to build a garden out of His creation, and tend to it as he wants, only propagating plants that are pleasing to him. And He tells the Israelites to systematically sacrifice lambs, but not their own children. Except that God puts this fate on His own son.

Remember that no sin is irredeemable, though. People hurt people they love all the time, sometimes in permanent ways. We do things out of love that are very hateful because we don't know how to love unless we learn it from God first. And we can't learn from God if we haven't listened. And even when we know what is right, we sometimes fuck it up because we are so morally retarded.

> Leviticus attempts to heal and prevent disease for humans, but it straight up dismisses animals, categorically in some cases, as irredeemable.

It only prohibits eating certain meats. And it's very unlikely that this is authentic.

> I get why this is hard for you, but we gotta be honest with each other. If you live in the US, you generally maim your pets because you don't want to have to love them as they are. You want to love them for how you want them to be.

I don't do that, the breeders already have it done.

> I feel like it is shameful to maim God's creation unnecessarily, but God told Adam to build a garden out of His creation, and tend to it as he wants, only propagating plants that are pleasing to him.

Before he could do wrong, yeah.

> And He tells the Israelites to systematically sacrifice lambs, but not their own children. Except that God puts this fate on His own son.

"Add your burnt offerings to your sacrifices and eat meat. Because I did not speak to your ancestors or command them in the day I brought them out of Egypt about burnt offerings and sacrifices." - Jeremiah 7:22
body_html:
Leviticus attempts to heal and prevent disease for humans, but it straight up dismisses animals, categorically in some cases, as irredeemable.

It only prohibits eating certain meats. And it's very unlikely that this is authentic.

I get why this is hard for you, but we gotta be honest with each other. If you live in the US, you generally maim your pets because you don't want to have to love them as they are. You want to love them for how you want them to be.

I don't do that, the breeders already have it done.

I feel like it is shameful to maim God's creation unnecessarily, but God told Adam to build a garden out of His creation, and tend to it as he wants, only propagating plants that are pleasing to him.

Before he could do wrong, yeah.

And He tells the Israelites to systematically sacrifice lambs, but not their own children. Except that God puts this fate on His own son.

"Add your burnt offerings to your sacrifices and eat meat. Because I did not speak to your ancestors or command them in the day I brought them out of Egypt about burnt offerings and sacrifices." - Jeremiah 7:22
